perturbation.original_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term "Post-Term Period" shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member's employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.changed_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term "Post-Term Period" shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of five (5) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member's employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.explanation: Increasing the non-compete period to five years may be considered unreasonably long in some states, rendering it unenforceable under state laws that restrict the duration of non-compete agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
perturbation.law_explanation: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600 generally prohibits non-compete agreements. While there are exceptions for the sale of a business, a five-year non-compete for an employee may be deemed an unlawful restraint of trade under California law, contradicting this statute.

perturbation.changed_text: 3. Injunctive Relief. Member acknowledges that any failure to comply with the requirements of this Agreement will cause Franchisor irreparable injury, and Member agrees to pay all court costs and attorney's fees incurred by Franchisor in obtaining specific performance of, or an injunction against violation of, the requirements of this Agreement. Member further waives any right to challenge the reasonableness of the attorney's fees.
perturbation.explanation: Forcing the member to waive the right to challenge the reasonableness of the attorney's fees is a violation of California law, as it removes their ability to ensure fairness in the fee assessment.
perturbation.law_explanation: California Civil Code Section 1717 allows a prevailing party to recover reasonable attorney's fees in contract actions, but implicitly assumes that the fees must be reasonable and subject to review. Waiving the right to challenge the reasonableness of fees undermines the court's ability to ensure fairness and compliance with this statute.

perturbation.explanation: Forfeiting vested retirement benefits due to violating a non-compete or confidentiality agreement may violate ERISA's anti-forfeiture provisions.
perturbation.law_explanation: 29 U.S.C. § 1053 generally prohibits the forfeiture of vested pension benefits. While there are limited exceptions, a broad forfeiture provision triggered by violating a non-compete agreement could violate ERISA if it applies to benefits that have already vested.
